chapter.htmlHeader: What should alert me to possible domestic violence and abuse?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Healthcare services should have a domestic violence and abuse policy and a designated person responsible for the response to domestic violence and abuse. Healthcare staff should be trained on how to recognize the signs of possible domestic violence and abuse, how to enquire sensitively and safely, the importance of confidentiality, and the organization’s process for responding to disclosure.

  • Indicators of possible domestic violence and abuse include:
    • Inconsistent health-seeking behaviour, such as:
      • Frequent appointments for vague symptoms.
      • Frequently missed appointments, including at antenatal clinics.
      • Non-concordance with treatment or premature discharge from hospital.
      • Repeated health consultations with no clear diagnosis. The person may describe themselves as ‘accident prone’ or ‘silly’ and provide a vague explanation of injuries.
    • Physical symptoms and signs, such as:
      • Injuries inconsistent with explanation of cause or the woman tries to hide or minimize the extent of injuries.
      • Repeated injury or multiple injuries at different stages of healing, all with vague or implausible explanations (particularly injuries to the breasts or abdomen).
      • Traumatic injury, especially if repeated and with vague or implausible explanations (for example burns, bites, cuts, or fractures).
      • Problems with the central nervous system (for example headaches, cognitive problems, and hearing loss).
      • Unexplained chronic gastrointestinal symptoms.
      • Unexplained genitourinary symptoms, including frequent bladder or kidney infections.
      • Chronic unexplained pain.
    • Reproductive/sexual health presentations, such as:
      • Unexplained gynaecological symptoms, including pelvic pain and sexual dysfunction.
      • Adverse reproductive outcomes, including multiple unintended pregnancies or terminations.
      • Delayed pregnancy care, miscarriage, premature labour, and stillbirth or concealed pregnancy.
      • Vaginal bleeding, recurrent sexually transmitted infections, or recurrent urinary tract infections.
    • Emotional or psychological symptoms, such as:
      • Symptoms of depression, fear, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder, and sleep disorders.
      • Self-harming, suicidal ideation, or suicide attempts.
      • Alcohol or drug misuse.
      • Evidence of self neglect.
    • Intrusive ‘other person’ present in consultations:
      • Partner or spouse, parent, grandparent (or, for elder abuse, a partner or family member) always attending appointments unnecessarily.
      • The person is submissive or afraid to speak in front of the partner or relative, escort, or spouse.
      • The escort is aggressive, dominant or over attentive, talking for the person, or refusing to leave the room.
      • It is important to recognize that the escort may also intentionally present as charming, pleasant, and agreeable, a tactic which, by contrast, may make the person experiencing domestic violence and abuse seem difficult and/or disordered in their thinking.
  • There is currently insufficient evidence to recommend screening or routine enquiry in healthcare settings regarding domestic violence and abuse, although a low threshold for enquiry is recommended.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Department of Health guideline Responding to domestic abuse: A resource for health professionals [DH, 2017], the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) guideline Domestic abuse [RCN, 2017], and the British Medical Association (BMA) guideline Domestic abuse [BMA, 2014], and draw on recommendations in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) public health guideline Domestic violence and abuse: multi-agency working [NICE, 2014] and the NICE Quality standard on Domestic violence and abuse [NICE, 2016].

  • The NICE guideline on domestic violence and abuse recommends that health and social care managers and professionals should ensure frontline staff are trained to recognize the indicators of domestic violence and abuse and can ask relevant questions to help people disclose past or current experiences of violence or abuse [NICE, 2014]. 
  • The indicators of possible domestic abuse are based on the Department of Health guideline [DH, 2017], the RCN guideline [RCN, 2017], and the BMA guideline [BMA, 2014].
    • The Department of Health points out that none of these indicators automatically indicates domestic violence and abuse, but even if the person chooses not to disclose at the present time, knowing that a healthcare professional is aware of the issues and is supportive will build trust and encourage them to disclose at a later date [DH, 2017].
  • The NICE guideline highlights that there is an ongoing debate about the effectiveness and desirability of screening and enquiry (routine or targeted) to identify people who are experiencing domestic violence and abuse. Although there is insufficient evidence to recommend this practice in healthcare settings, asking people routinely about domestic violence and abuse in some specialized healthcare settings is considered good practice by professionals in those fields [NICE, 2014]. An expert reviewer of this CKS topic also recommends a low threshold for enquiry about domestic violence and abuse.
